'''Jan Bert Lieve Vertonghen''' ({{IPA-nl|ˈjɑn vərˈtɔŋə(n)}}; born 24 April 1987) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]]. Mainly a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]], he can also play as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left back]].
He began his senior career at Dutch club [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] in 2006 and totalled 220 games and 28 goals for them across all competitions, serving as their captain since 2011. He won two [[Eredivisie]] and two [[KNVB Cup]] titles during his time at the club, and in 2012 he was named [[Dutch Footballer of the Year]]. Vertonghen transferred to Tottenham in July 2012, and made the [[PFA Team of the Year]] in his first [[Premier League]] season, going on to make over 200 appearances for Spurs and winning their player of the year award in 2018.
Vertonghen made his international debut for Belgium in 2007 and his 111 caps (including [[Belgium national football team results – unofficial matches#2010s|three unofficial games]], according to FIFA rules) are the most in the history of the national team. He was part of Belgian squads that came fourth at the [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2008 Olympics]] and reached the quarter-finals of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] as well as third place at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].
==Early life== Vertonghen was born in [[Sint-Niklaas]], Belgium, to Ria Mattheeuws and Paul Vertonghen.<ref name=IndyDec2012>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/exclusive-interview-jan-vertonghen-spurred-on-by-tottenhams-fight-for-fourth-8418339.html |title=Exclusive interview: Jan Vertonghen spurred on by Tottenham's fight |last=Wallace |first=Sam |date=15 December 2012 |newspaper=The Independent |access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.90min.com/posts/4304829-spurs-star-s-mother-admits-white-hart-lane-exit-could-be-close-due-to-homesickness-issues|title=Spurs Star's Mother Admits White Hart Lane Exit Could Be Close Due to 'Homesickness' Issues|last=Flavius|first=Kavan|date=21 December 2016|website=90min.com |access-date=24 December 2016}}</ref> He has two brothers, Ward and Lode; both have played football.<ref name=IndyDec2012/>
==Club career== ===Ajax=== [[File:Shevchenko vertonghen.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Vertonghen marking [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]]'s [[Andriy Shevchenko]] in 2010]] After spending time at VK Tielrode and [[Germinal Beerschot]], Vertonghen moved to the Netherlands and signed a contract with the youth academy of [[Eredivisie]] side [[AFC Ajax]]. He began as a midfielder but then became a regular at centre-back for Ajax.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jan Vertonghen tevreden met positie bij Ajax|url=http://www.voetbalcentraal.nl/nieuws/39673/jan-vertonghen-tevreden-met-positie-bij-ajax-list|work=Voetbal Centraal|date=12 November 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref> During his time in the [[Jong Ajax|reserves]], he became known for an incident in a [[2005–06 KNVB Cup|2006 KNVB Cup]] game against [[Cambuur Leeuwarden]], his first home game at the [[Amsterdam Arena]], where he scored a goal to put Ajax 3–0 up. He had attempted a back pass to the Cambuur goalkeeper while a teammate was receiving treatment but instead the ball went into the goal. Since it was unintentional, Ajax allowed Cambuur to score a goal in return.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gatorade Cup: Young Ajax beat Cambuur in memorable game|url=http://www.ajaxusa.com/news/2005-2006/gatorade-cup-young-ajax-beat-cambuur-in-memorable-game.html|publisher=Ajax USA|date=20 September 2005}}</ref>
====Loan to RKC==== On 23 August 2006, Vertonghen made his first team debut in the [[2006–07 UEFA Champions League#Third qualifying round|Champions League third qualifying round]] against [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]]. He made his first start and Eredivisie debut in a 6–0 win over [[Willem II Tilburg|Willem II]] at the Amsterdam ArenA and would play another two matches for the first half of the season. After the winter break, he was sent on [[loan (sports)|loan]] to struggling [[RKC Waalwijk]] for the remainder of the season. At RKC, he would play 12 matches in which he scored three times, but he was unable to help the team avoid relegation to the [[Eerste Divisie]].
Vertonghen returned to Ajax for the [[2007–08 Eredivisie|2007–08 season]], where he was tipped for stardom, but was unable to break through due to a severe injury and the presence of central defenders [[John Heitinga]] and [[Thomas Vermaelen]]. [[Johan Cruyff]] had made no secret of his admiration for the left-footed youngster who can handle any left-sided position in defence and midfield, opting, on 26 September 2008, to extend his contract to 30 June 2013.
====Breakthrough at Ajax==== The [[2008–09 Eredivisie|2008–09 season]] was a breakthrough season for the young defender. After John Heitinga left for [[Atlético Madrid]], Vertonghen became Thomas Vermaelen's first-choice partner in central defence; the former started 23 of the 26 games he played in and scored four goals. On 28 September, he scored a rare double against [[Vitesse Arnhem|Vitesse]] in a 3–0 win. Although sustaining an injury from training during the week, he played in the match against [[FC Groningen|Groningen]] on 24 January, billed as a "must-win" match by coach [[Marco van Basten]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Preview: FC Groningen vs Ajax Amsterdam|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/preview?id=249496&cc=3888&league=NED.1|work=[[ESPN Soccernet]]|date=25 January 2009}}</ref> Vertonghen was unfortunate enough to be sent off for two yellow cards as Ajax lost 1–0. He was out for a month after sustaining a hamstring injury in an away win on 1 March against [[FC Utrecht|Utrecht]], but his return lasted only several games after his season was prematurely ended after aggravating another injury.
====Rising importance under Jol==== [[File:Vertonghen Stekelenburg.jpg|thumb|Vertonghen with [[Maarten Stekelenburg]].]] Under new coach [[Martin Jol]], Vertonghen retained his place in the starting line-up for the [[2009–10 Eredivisie|2009–10 season]]. Despite injuring his toe while on international duty against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] the previous week, he scored his first goal of the season, a free kick, in a 6–0 thrashing of [[NAC Breda]] on 13 September.<ref>{{cite news|title=Match Report: Ajax Amsterdam vs NAC Breda|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=271828&cc=3888&league=NED.1|work=ESPN Soccernet|date=13 September 2009}}</ref> With the departure of Thomas Vermaelen to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], he and fellow Belgian [[Toby Alderweireld]] become the first choice centre-back pairing and soon became a firm fans' favourite.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jol: 'Vertonghen is een echte Hollander'|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/sport/video/extern-jol-vertonghen-is-een-echte-hollander.aspx|work=[[Gazet van Antwerpen]]|date=26 September 2009|accessdate=27 October 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref> Despite Ajax's erratic form in the latter weeks leading up to the winter break, he turned in some strong performances and attracted the interest of a number of clubs, including [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], but he played down the rumours, stating his intent to at least see out his contract with Ajax.<ref>{{cite news|title='Jan Vertonghen in beeld bij FC Barcelona'|url=http://www.depers.nl/sport/441704/Vertonghen-in-beeld-bij-Barça.html|work=[[De Pers]]|date=17 February 2010|language=Dutch|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100224031455/http://www.depers.nl/sport/441704/Vertonghen-in-beeld-bij-Bar%C3%A7a.html|archivedate=24 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Guardiola estaría siguiendo a Vertonghen|url=http://www.sport.es/default.asp?idpublicacio_PK=44&idioma=CAS&idnoticia_PK=687794&idseccio_PK=803|work=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|date=16 February 2010|language=Spanish}}</ref>
After the winter break, Ajax went on a nine-game unbeaten streak in the league, with Vertonghen playing a key role. Their run of six consecutive clean sheets was ended in a 4–1 home win over [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] when the visiting side were awarded a penalty. Vertonghen was linked with a move to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], and later he was also linked with [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], stating, "I've heard Milan Director [[Adriano Galliani]] talk about me after the Champions League match in [[San Siro]] and his words were very flattering."<ref>{{cite web|title=Vertonghen linked to Milan|url=http://goal-arena.com/2011/02/vertonghen-linked-to-milan|publisher=Goal-arena.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110216043647/http://goal-arena.com/2011/02/vertonghen-linked-to-milan/|archivedate=16 February 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Basis Elftal Ajax 14Sep2011.jpg|thumb|Vertonghen (top right) [[captain (association football)|captain]]ing Ajax.]] Vertonghen stated on numerous occasions late in the [[2010–11 Eredivisie|2010–11 season]] that he was considering leaving Ajax at the end of that season.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Vertonghen weighing up move |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11906_6722248,00.html |work=Sky Sports |date=4 February 2011|accessdate=22 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=Ajax star targets Prem switch |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6921360,00.html |work=Sky Sports |date=8 May 2011}}</ref> In May 2011, [[Frank de Boer]] confirmed [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] boss [[Roberto Mancini]] was present at the [[2010-11 KNVB Cup|2011 KNVB Cup Final]] held on 7 May 2011, where Vertonghen's side lost 3–2 to [[FC Twente|Twente]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_6925317,00.html|title=City keep eye on Vertonghen|date=13 May 2011|work=Sky Sports}}</ref> Mancini was reportedly scouting Vertonghen to strengthen his side after they had qualified for the [[UEFA Champions League]] 2011–12 campaign.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story/_/id/918003/man-city-scout-jan-vertonghen,-axel-witsel-and-kevin-de-bruyne?cc=5901|title=City scout Belgian trio|date=10 May 2011|work=ESPN Soccernet}}</ref>
====Breakthrough under De Boer==== During the [[2011–12 Eredivisie]] season, Vertonghen emerged as one of Ajax's best players, demonstrating his versatility to cover multiple positions after Ajax had let several regular players out on long-term loans. After an impressive season, including a performance for which he was singled out for praise against Manchester United in the [[UEFA Europa League]] Round of 16, he was named the 2011–12 [[Dutch Footballer of the Year|Eredivisie Player of the Year]]. Named team captain by [[Frank de Boer]], he led his Ajax to their second title in a row, scoring eight goals in 31 league games, highlighting his attacking strengths. Also, for the second time, he dropped the Championship plate. "Now it falls on my toe – this plate just does not like me," Vertonghen said.<ref>{{cite web|title=Season review: Netherlands|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=ned/news/newsid=1800379.html#season+review+netherlands|publisher=by Berend Scholten on UEFA.com|accessdate=22 May 2012}}</ref>
===Tottenham Hotspur=== ====2012–13 season==== Throughout the 2011–12 season, Vertonghen was linked with English club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and publicly expressed his desire to make the move to [[White Hart Lane]] ahead of numerous other teams. A key factor in this was his desire to play as a centre-back, with Arsenal wanting to use him as a defensive midfielder. On 8 July 2012, Tottenham agreed a fee and terms for Vertonghen subject to a medical. On 12 July, Tottenham announced that they had officially completed the signing of Vertonghen, for an amount around 12 million Euros, after he successfully completed his medical.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jan Vertonghen completes Tottenham move from Ajax|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18761297|publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tottenham on the verge of completing transfer of Jan Vertonghen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/jul/08/tottenham-signing-jan-vertonghen-ajax|publisher=The Guardian |date=8 July 2012 |accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> Vertonghen took part in his first game as a Tottenham player in a 3–2 friendly win against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on 14 July, then later scored his first goal for the club on 26 September in a 3–0 win against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] in the third round of the [[Football League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19645193 |title=Carlisle 0–3 Tottenham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=29 September 2012}}</ref>
Vertonghen scored his first [[Premier League]] goal against Manchester United in a historic 2–3 win at [[Old Trafford]], although this was later ruled to be an own goal by [[Jonny Evans]].<ref>[http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/261615/report "Spurs end United hoodoo"] Skysport. 29 September 2012. Retrieved 29 September 2012.</ref> He scored in the league for Tottenham on 16 December, the only goal of the game, in a win at White Hart Lane against [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>[http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/football/premier-league/2012-2013/tottenham-hotspur-swansea-city-515473.html "Premier League – Vertonghen strike sinks Swansea"] UK Yahoo. 16 December 2012. Retrieved 17 December 2012.</ref> Vertonghen then scored a brace in a losing effort against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 10 March. He was named [[Premier League Player of the Month]] for March 2013, making himself the second Belgian and the 12th Spurs player to win the award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vertonghen and Moyes win Barclays awards|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2012-13/apr/david-moyes-and-jan-vertonghen-win-barclays-march-awards.html|work=Barclays Premier League|date=5 April 2013|accessdate=21 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729045920/http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2012-13/apr/david-moyes-and-jan-vertonghen-win-barclays-march-awards.html|archivedate=29 July 2013}}</ref> On 11 April 2013, Vertonghen was sent-off against [[FC Basel|Basel]] during Tottenham's [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League#Quarter-finals|Europa League quarter-final second leg]]. Tottenham went on to lose the tie 4–1 on penalties after a 4–4 draw on aggregate.<ref>{{cite web|title=FC Basel 2–2 Tottenham (agg 4–4)|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22023547|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 April 2013}}</ref> Vertonghen was named in the 2012–13 [[PFA Team of the Year]], alongside [[Rio Ferdinand]], [[Leighton Baines]] and [[Pablo Zabaleta]] in defence.<ref name=1213PFA>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22331030 |title=Gareth Bale wins PFA Player of Year and Young Player awards |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2013 |accessdate=5 May 2018}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== [[File:Chelsea 3 Spurs 0 (15953303611).jpg|thumb|right|180px|Vertonghen (right) playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2014.]] At the start of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]], Vertonghen appeared to be out of favour with new manager [[Mauricio Pochettino]]. The Argentine gave Vertonghen limited games, preferring [[Younès Kaboul]] and [[Federico Fazio]]. However, Kaboul lost his place to Vertonghen, who formed an effective partnership with Fazio. Together, the pair, over the span of 15 games, celebrated 11 wins and only suffered one loss. Vertonghen helped Spurs to reach the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]] and started the game on 1 March 2015, but Tottenham lost to [[Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|rival]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] 2–0.<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== Vertonghen was joined in defence by former Ajax teammate and compatriot Alderweireld at the start of the [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16 season]]. Over the first ten games of the season, Vertonghen and Alderweireld played ten out of the opening ten games together, with Spurs suffering only one loss during the span. In late January 2016, he damaged his medial knee-ligament and did not play for 11 weeks.<ref name="injury"/> He returned in the home match against Manchester United on 10 April 2016, which finished in a 3–0 win, the first home league win for Tottenham against Manchester United since 2001.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/660766/Tottenham-Jan-Vertonghen-Manchester-United-Premier-League-news-rumours |title=Tottenham star: Why Manchester United win was easy |first=James |last= Gray|date=13 April 2016 |work=Sunday Express}}</ref> His partnership with Alderweireld in the defence was recognised as being crucial for the club which had the joint-lowest number of goals conceded in the Premier League that season.<ref name="guardian 2016"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/features/the-big-interview/the-big-interview-with-jan-vertonghen-120416/ |title=THE Big Interview- Jan Vertonghen|date= 12 April 2016 |work=Tottenham Hotspur}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 2 December 2016, Vertonghen signed a new contract with Tottenham until 2019.<ref name="guardian 2016">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/02/jan-vertonghen-tottenham-new-contract|title=Jan Vertonghen signs new deal with Tottenham until 2019|website=The Guardian|date=2 December 2016|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> However, in mid January 2017, Vertonghen suffered an ankle ligament injury that would see him out of action for five weeks.<ref name="injury">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/17/tottenham-jan-vertonghen-ankle-injury |title=Tottenham’s Jan Vertonghen facing up to two months out with ankle injury |first= Dominic |last=Fifield|date= 17 January 2017 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> He returned to the team on 19 February in the fifth round [[2016–17 FA Cup|FA Cup]] match against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] at [[Craven Cottage]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/tottenham-news-jan-vertonghen-targeting-europa-league-and-fa-cup-trophies-this-season-a7589521.html |title=Jan Vertonghen targeting Europa League and FA Cup trophies this season as Tottenham get back in the groove |first=Jack|last= Pitt-Brooke |date= 20 February 2017 |work=The Independent }}</ref> This season, Vertonghen was part of the Tottenham defence that achieved the best defensive record for the club, with only 26 goals conceded in the Premier League (and only 9 conceded in home league games), 6 better than the previous record of 32 conceded that was set in the [[1908–09 in English football|1908–09 season]] in the [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/2016-17-in-numbers-few-goals-conceded-020617/ |title=2016–17 in Numbers – New Defensive Records|date= 2 June 2017 |work=Tottenham Hotspur }}</ref> He was considered then one of the best defenders in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.football365.com/news/football365s-top-ten-defenders-of-the-season |title=Football365's top ten defenders of the season |date= 26 April 2017 |work=Football365 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/11/17/arsenal-beware-how-jan-vertonghen-has-become-the-premier-leagues-best-centre-back-7085021/ |title=Arsenal beware: How Jan Vertonghen has become the Premier League’s best centre-back|work=Metro |first=Ewan |last=Roberts |date= 17 November 2017 }}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== On 7 January 2018, Vertonghen scored his first goal for the club since October 2013, a 30-yard strike in the 3–0 win over [[AFC Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] in the third round of the [[2017–18 FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2018-01-07/harry-kane-is-back-among-the-goals-as-spurs-dispatch-wimbledon/ |title=Harry Kane is back among the goals as Spurs dispatch Wimbledon |date=7 January 2018|work=ITV}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== In the opening game of the [[2018–19 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2018–19 season]] against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], Vertonghen scored Tottenham's first goal of the season 8 minutes into the game, helping the team to a 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://talksport.com/football/410025/tottenham-hotspur-jan-vertonghen-goal-line-technology-newcastle/ |title=Tottenham Hotspur news: Jan Vertonghen claims he has been converted to goal-line technology after Newcastle win |date=12 August 2018 |work=talkSport}}</ref> However, he suffered a hamstring injury in the game against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield]] on 29 September, and was out for two months,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45827420 |title=Jan Vertonghen: Injured Tottenham defender expected to be out until December|work=BBC Sports |date=11 October 2018}}</ref> returning to the starting lineup in the [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] game against [[Inter Milan]] in late November.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/nov/28/tottenham-internazionale-champions-league-match-report |title=Christian Eriksen pounces to give Spurs crucial victory over Internazionale |first=David |last=Hytner|date=28 November 2018 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> His contract with Tottenham was extended to 2020 in December 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46609966 |title=Jan Vertonghen: Tottenham extend Belgian defender's deal|date=18 December 2018 |work=BBC Sport }}</ref> In the [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League knockout phase|last 16 round]] home game against [[Borussia Dortmund]] in the Champions League, Vertonghen played in the less familiar position of left [[Defender (association football)#Wing-back|wing back]], scoring one goal and providing one assist in a game that finished 3–0. He received wide praise for his performance in this game,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/tottenham-vs-borussia-dortmund-vertonghen-goals-son-llorente-watch-video-highlights-replay-a8778546.html |title=Tottenham vs Dortmund: In praise of Jan Vertonghen, Mauricio Pochettino’s unlikely match-winner |first=Luke |last=Brown|date=14 February 2019 |work=The Independent }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2019/02/13/gary-lineker-and-alan-shearer-rave-about-tottenham-hotspurs-jan/ |title=Gary Lineker and Alan Shearer rave about Tottenham Hotspur''s Jan Vertonghen on Twitter |first=Dan |last=Coombs |date= 13 February 2019 |work=HITC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/02/14/does-jan-vertonghen-rank-footballs-great-position-performances/ |title=Where does Jan Vertonghen rank in football's great out-of-position performances? |first=Daniel|last= Zeqiri |date=14 February 2019|work=The Telegraph }}</ref> and he was named the Champions League Player of the Week by UEFA.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/2019/february/jan-named-ucl-player-of-the-week/ |title=Jan Vertonghen named UCL Player of the Week |date= 15 February 2019 |work=Tottenham Hotspur}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Vertonghen Belgium National Team vs USA 2013 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Vertonghen with [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] in 2013]] Vertonghen made his international debut at the under-21 level in 2006 and played in the [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2007 UEFA U21 Championships]].
On 2 June 2007, he made his senior debut for the [[Belgium national football team|national team]] in a 2–1 loss against [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]]. He was also selected for the 2008 Olympics and played in every match as the Belgians unexpectedly took fourth place.
In the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2010 World Cup qualifying]], he began to establish himself as a regular, initially at centre-back as former Ajax teammate [[Thomas Vermaelen]]'s partner. He scored the opening goal, also his first ever international goal,<ref>{{cite news|title=Vertonghen: "Moeten dringend eens maturiteit tonen"|url=http://belgiumsoccer.be/nieuws/lees/2009-08-13/vertonghen-moeten-dringend-eens-maturiteit-tonen|language=Dutch|work=Belgiumsoccer.be|date=13 August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706133000/http://www.belgiumsoccer.be/nieuws/lees/2009-08-13/vertonghen-moeten-dringend-eens-maturiteit-tonen|archivedate=6 July 2011}}</ref> in an August 2009 friendly against the Czech Republic that ended in a 3–1 loss. On 7 September 2009, in a [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|World Cup qualifying away match]] against Spain, he injured his toe and had to be stretchered off and substituted in the 29th minute. The match ended bad as well; a 5–0 loss.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vertonghen twee weken uit de strijd|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/telesport/voetbal/4777976/__Teen_zit_Vertonghen_dwars__.html|work=[[De Telegraaf]]|date=7 September 2009|accessdate= 13 September 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref> Now he usually plays as leftback as Vermaelen and [[Vincent Kompany]] are the preferred pairing in central defence.<ref>{{cite news|title=L’équipe-type prend forme|url=http://www.lalibre.be/sports/football/article/543707/l-equipe-type-prend-forme.html|work=[[La Libre Belgique]]|date=19 November 2009|language=French}}</ref> He was back in the starting eleven for the friendly against Hungary, a 3–0 win<ref>{{cite news|title=België wint oefenpot tegen Hongarije: 3–0|url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/sport/voetbal-binnenland/aid878871/belgie-wint-oefenpot-tegen-hongarije-3-0.aspx|work=Gazet van Antwerpen|date=14 November 2009|language=Dutch}}</ref> and the 1–0 loss to Croatia the following March.
On 13 May 2014, Vertonghen was named in [[2014 FIFA World Cup squads#Belgium|Belgium's squad]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Adnan Januzaj included in Belgium's World Cup squad|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27395150|accessdate=15 May 2014|newspaper=[[BBC Sport]]|date=13 May 2014}}</ref> In the team's opening match against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]], the African side was awarded a penalty after Vertonghen pulled down [[Sofiane Feghouli]] and received a yellow card. Feghouli scored for Algeria from the penalty spot,<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25285127 Felini Inspires Belgium to Comeback Win – BBC Sport online], Accessed 17 June 2014</ref> but Belgium came back to win 2–1. He was then replaced by Thomas Vermaelen in the starting line-up for the second match against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] on 22 June.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285242|title=Brazil v Russia|date=22 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014|work=BBC}}</ref> After 31 minutes, however, Vermaelen was taken off with an injury and replaced by Vertonghen.<ref name=bbc/> In the final group match, Vertonghen [[Captain (association football)|captained]] the team and scored the winning goal as Belgium beat [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] 1–0.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285474|title=South Korea 0–1 Belgium|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=27 June 2014|work=BBC}}</ref>
Early in the 2014–15 season, Vertonghen knocked a child unconscious with a misplaced shot during a training session with the Belgian squad.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/jan-vertonghen-knocks-girl-unconscious-after-a-stray-pass-while-training-for-belgium-9708768.html|title=Jan Vertonghen knocks girl unconscious after a stray pass while training for Belgium|work=The Independent|date=3 September 2014|accessdate=17 July 2016}}</ref> In 2016, he injured two ligaments in his ankle in an accident while training before the quarter-final against Wales during [[UEFA Euro 2016]], and as a result missed the match that Belgium lost.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/30/jan-vertonghen-belgium-euro-2016-quarter-final-wales |title=Jan Vertonghen ruled out of Euro 2016 after tearing ankle ligaments |date=30 June 2016 |work=The Guardian }}</ref>
Eleven years to the day on from his international début, against the same opposition (Portugal) Vertonghen won his 100th [[cap (sport)|cap]] (the first in Belgian history), which was presented to him by his mother.<ref>{{cite news|title=These sports stars proved that their mums are the real superstars|first=Jagroop|last=Shinbt|date=4 June 2018|accessdate=4 June 2018|work=bbc.co.uk/bbcthree|publisher=BBC Three|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/bbcthree/article/615c42f0-39be-43fb-8235-9b7ee8e9ae83}}</ref>
At the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia, Vertonghen initiated the scoring in Belgium’s second-half comeback from a 0–2 deficit against Japan, heading from 20 yards out to the far post in a 3–2 comeback victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Live blog|date=2 July 2018|accessdate=2 July 2018|work=fifa.com|publisher=FIFA|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/match/300331551/}}</ref>
==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|9 March 2019}}<ref>{{cite web |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/players/stats?id=125086&league=NED.1&season=2009&cc=5739 |title=Jan Vertonghen Statistics |accessdate=15 May 2012 | publisher=ESPN Soccernet}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler/Jan-Vertonghen.htm |title=Jan Vertonghen |accessdate=15 May 2012 | publisher=[[Voetbal International]]}}</ref> [[File:Jan Vertonghen and Nacer Chadli vs Arsenal - 1 September 2013.jpg|thumb|upright|Vertonghen alongside compatriot [[Nacer Chadli]] playing for Tottenham Hotspur in the [[North London derby]] against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], 2013]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2019}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2019}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Harry Winks | image = France - England U19, 20150331 51.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Winks playing for [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] in 2015 | fullname = Harry Billy Winks<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bdfutbol.com/en/j/j84146.html |title=Winks: Harry Billy Winks: Player |publisher=BDFutbol |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|2|2|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/7488/Harry-Winks/overview |title=Harry Winks: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Hemel Hempstead]], England | height = {{convert|1.78|m|ftin|order=flip}}<ref name=Soccerway>{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/harry-winks/274470/ |title=H. Winks: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | clubnumber = 8 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2014 | youthclubs1 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Under-23s and Academy|Tottenham Hotspur]] | years1 = 2014– | clubs1 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps1 = 62 | goals1 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2014 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps2 = 2 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 6 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 8 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2016– | nationalteam5 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps5 = 2 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | nationalyears6 = 2017– | nationalteam6 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps6 = 3 | nationalgoals6 = 0 | club-update = 11:02, 15 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 11:02, 15 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Harry Billy Winks''' (born 2 February 1996) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|TottenhH}} club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
==Early and personal life== Harry Winks was born to Anita and Gary Winks. He has Spanish ancestry through his mother and grandparents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/tottenham-hotspur/story/3167719/tottenhams-harry-winks-i-consider-myself-english-and-i-want-to-play-for-england |title=Spurs' Harry Winks: 'I consider myself English and I want to play for England'|first=Dan |last= Kilpatrick |date=28 July 2017 |publisher=ESPN |accessdate=14 February 2019}}</ref> He was born and raised in [[Hemel Hempstead]] and was educated at [[Cavendish School, Hemel Hempstead|Cavendish School]].<ref name=Soccerway/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tringtoday.co.uk/sport/football/hemel-hot-shot-harry-ready-to-earn-his-spurs-1-4051385 |title=Hemel hot shot ready to earn his Spurs |website=Tring Today |accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> Winks is a [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] fan; he attended his first match at [[White Hart Lane]] when he was six. He was invited to train at Tottenham's development centre in [[St Albans]] after attending a summer football camp ran by an academy coach when he was five, and joined the Tottenham Academy at the age of six.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jan/27/harry-winks-spurs-tottenham|title=Harry Winks: ‘The buzz I get from playing for Tottenham … I don’t think it will ever go’ |first=David |last=Hytner|date=27 January 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=14 February 2019}}</ref><ref name="Pitt-Brooke"/>
==Club career== ===Tottenham Hotspur=== ====Early career==== Winks is a product of the Tottenham Hotspur youth system. During the [[2013–14 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2013–14 season]], he regularly trained with the first-team squad and was named on the senior bench for the first time in a Premier League tie against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 30 March 2014, remaining an unused substitute in a 4–0 loss at [[Anfield]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Emons |first1=Michael |title=Liverpool 4–0 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26703761 |accessdate=13 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 March 2014}}</ref> On 27 July 2014, Winks signed his first professional contract with Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11675/9395683/tottenham-starlet-harry-winks-agrees-professional-deal |title=Premier League: Tottenham midfielder Harry Winks agrees professional deal |first=Pete |last=O'Rourke |date=26 July 2014 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> According to Winks, [[Mauricio Pochettino]] said that he wanted to sign Winks immediately after watching videos of his performances.<ref name="Pitt-Brooke">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/harry-winks-tottenham-spurs-mauricio-pochettino-interview-a7549816.html |title=Harry Winks: How trusting Mauricio Pochettino saw me break into the Tottenham first-team |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |date=27 January 2017 |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> He made his first team debut on 27 November 2014 in the [[UEFA Europa League]] group against [[FK Partizan]] in a 1–0 home win at [[White Hart Lane]], replacing [[Paulinho (footballer)|Paulinho]] after 87 minutes.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chowdhury |first1=Saj |title=Tottenham 1–0 Partizan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30204407 |accessdate=13 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2014}}</ref>
On 6 July 2015, Winks signed a new contract with Tottenham until 2018, with the option of an additional year.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/new-deal-for-winks-060715/ |title=New deal for Winks |accessdate=7 July 2015 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref> He was given the number 29 shirt, which was included on the club's list of first-team numbers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/squad-numbers-070815/ |title=2015–16 Premier League squad numbers announced 7 August 2015 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |date=7 August 2015}}</ref> Winks made his first appearance of the season as a late substitute in a 3–1 win against [[Qarabağ FK]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34203688 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 3–1 FK Qarabag |date=17 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== On 27 August 2016, he made his Premier League debut, replacing [[Christian Eriksen]] in the last minute of the match in a 1–1 draw at home to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/08/27/tottenham-vs-liverpool-live-score-and-goal-updates-from-premier/ |title=Tottenham 1 Liverpool 1: Danny Rose scores late equaliser to cancel out James Milner penalty |first=Sam |last=Wallace |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=27 August 2016}}</ref>
On 19 November 2016, Winks made his full debut against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], performing well and scoring his first ever goal for Spurs to level the match at 1–1. Tottenham went on to win the match 3–2 in a dramatic finish at White Hart Lane after scoring two late goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/19/tottenham-hotspur-west-ham-united-premier-league-match-report |title=Harry Kane's two late goals earn Tottenham victory over West Ham |first=Alan |last=Smith |date=19 November 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref> Winks made his debut in the FA Cup on 8 January 2017, when he was selected for the team in the match against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] of the third round. Tottenham went on to win the match 2–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38481612 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 2–0 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |author=Rostance, Tom |date=8 January 2017 |accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> On 14 February 2017, Winks signed a new contract with Tottenham, keeping him at the club until 2022.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/10767558/harry-winks-signs-new-tottenham-contract |title=Harry Winks signs new Tottenham contract |publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> During an away match against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 1 April 2017 in the Premier League, Winks suffered an injury when he tumbled into the Burnley dugout,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39390125 |title=Burnley 0–2 Tottenham |publisher=BBC Sport |author=Stelton, Jack |date=1 April 2017 |accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> and was later taken to hospital for a scan on his ankle.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39469425 |title=Harry Winks: Tottenham midfielder taken to hospital with ankle injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 April 2017 |accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref> Spurs announced on 4 April that Winks would be sidelined by the injury to his ankle ligament for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39496157 |title=Harry Winks: Tottenham midfielder ruled out for the rest of the season |date=4 April 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 April 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== Winks began the [[2017–18 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2017–18 season]] as substitutes in three early games after recovering from his injury.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/tottenham-team-news-vs-barnsley-carabao-cup-harry-winks-dele-alli-a7954686.html |title=Harry Winks set to make first Tottenham start in six months after recovering from ankle injury |first=Jack |last=Pitt-Brooke |date=19 September 2017 |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref> He made his first start of the season in the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] tie against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] that finished 1–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/tottenham-hotspur/story/3208863/tottenhams-harry-winks-i-feel-like-im-100-percent-now-following-ankle-injury |title=Tottenham's Harry Winks: 'I feel like I'm 100 percent now' following injury |date=20 September 2017 |first=Dan |last=Kilpatrick |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> He next started in the match in [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] away game against [[APOEL FC]], and his performance earned him praise from [[Mauricio Pochettino]] as the "perfect midfielder".<ref name = "unlock">{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/11059148/mauricio-pochettino-tottenhams-harry-winks-can-unlock-defences |title=Mauricio Pochettino: Tottenham's Harry Winks can unlock defences |first=Allan |last=Valente |date=29 September 2017 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> After only one previous start in the Premier League for the club this season (in a 4–0 win against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]]) and four Premier League starts including last season, he gained his first call-up for the national squad.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/02/harry-winks-england-call-up-jones-delph-injured |title=Harry Winks earns England call-up after Fabian Delph and Phil Jones withdraw |first=Dominic |last=Fifield |date=2 October 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/10/05/harry-winkss-four-premier-league-starts-enough-experience-shine/ |title=Why Harry Winks's four Premier League starts is more than enough experience to shine for England |first=Alistair |last=Tweedale |date=5 October 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> He received plaudits for his performance in the UEFA Champions League game away against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] where he was judged to have held his own against [[Luka Modrić]] and [[Toni Kroos]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/real-madrid-tottenham-champions-league-harry-winks-shines-harry-kane-cristiano-ronaldo-a8005891.html |title=Harry Winks shines at Real Madrid as Tottenham midfielder proves he has the most important thing – Mauricio Pochettino's trust |first=Ed |last=Malyon |date=17 October 2017 |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thenational.ae/sport/football/a-nudge-to-winks-tottenham-s-promising-star-must-keep-feet-to-ground-1.668730 |title=A nudge to Winks: Tottenham's promising star must keep feet to ground |first=John |last=McAuley |date=19 October 2017 |newspaper=The National}}</ref> However, he picked up a niggling ankle injury in the match against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 5 November 2017, which led to him missing final three months of this season after trying initially to play some games through the discomfort.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/tottenham-hotspur/367/blog/post/3422022/harry-winks-now-the-forgotten-man-for-both-spurs-and-englands-world-cup-squad |title=Harry Winks' injury could spoil his Tottenham, World Cup dreams |date=16 March 2018 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> He signed a new contract on 17 May 2018, keeping him at Tottenham until 2023.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/11376031/harry-winks-signs-new-tottenham-contract-until-2023 |title=Harry Winks signs new Tottenham contract until 2023 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== After a long period out through an injury that required surgery,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11675/11389224/tottenham-midfielder-harry-winks-undergoes-sucessful-ankle-surgery |title=Tottenham midfielder Harry Winks undergoes successful ankle surgery |date=29 May 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> Winks returned to the squad in the [[2018–19 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2018–19 season]] in the home game against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], appearing as a late substitute.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.football.london/tottenham-hotspur-fc/players/harry-winks-spurs-team-news-15060260 |title=Tottenham ace Harry Winks outlines what he has done differently in his recovery from injury |first=Lee |last=Wilmot |date=25 August 2018 |website=Football.london}}</ref> He made his first start of the season in the game against Liverpool that Spurs lost 2–1.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/tottenhams-harry-winks-played-through-the-pain-against-liverpool-but-at-what-cost/ |title=Tottenham's Harry Winks played through the pain against Liverpool but at what cost? |first=Sam |last=Cunningham |newspaper=i |date=16 September 2018}}</ref> In the away match against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in January 2019, he scored a last minute winning goal to win 2–1, his first goal for the club since November 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/20/fulham-vs-tottenham-premier-league-live-score-latest-updates/ |title=Harry Winks breaks Fulham hearts with last minute winner but Dele Alli adds to Spurs' injury concerns |first1=Jason |last1=Burt|first2= JJ |last2=Bull|date=20 January 2019|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref>
==International career== Winks has represented England up to senior level. Before this, he was eligible to represent [[Spain national football team|Spain]] as well as England.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/tottenham-hotspur/story/3167719/tottenhams-harry-winks-i-consider-myself-english-and-i-want-to-play-for-england |title=Spurs' Harry Winks: 'I consider myself English and I want to play for England' |first=Dan |last=Kilpatrick |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> He was part of the [[England national under-20 football team|under-20 squad]] for the Mercedes-Benz Elite Cup in Germany in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/sep/under-20s-squad-named-for-trip-to-germany-300915 |title=England Under-20s squad named for Mercedes Elite Cup in Germany |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association}}</ref> Winks made his [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] debut on 14 November 2016 where he started in [[England national under-21 football team|England]]'s friendly 3–2 defeat to [[France national under-21 football team|France]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37896448 |title=France-U21 3–2 England-U21 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 November 2016}}</ref>
On 2 October 2017, Winks received his first call up to the [[England national football team|senior England squad]], for their [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifiers]] against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] and [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Pitt-Brooke |first1=Jack |last2=Delaney |first2=Miguel |title=England call up Harry Winks to replace injured Fabian Delph and Phil Jones |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/england-call-up-harry-winks-to-squad-to-face-slovenia-a7979581.html |accessdate=2 October 2017 |newspaper=The Independent |date=2 October 2017}}</ref> He made his debut when starting in England's 1–0 away win over Lithuania, which was the team's final match in their successful 2018 FIFA World Cup qualification campaign. Phil McNulty of BBC Sport stated that, on the night, Winks was "England's best performer. Neat and tidy and almost scored. Eye-catching among so much mediocrity".<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Lithuania 0–1 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41457291 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 October 2017 |accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> Winks missed the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] due to injury, but returned to the England squad in the [[2018–19 UEFA Nations League]] away match against Spain. He helped England to a 3–2 win, the first competitive home defeat for Spain since 2003 and England's first win in Spain in 31 years, in what was judged a "self-assured" performance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/10/15/harry-winksproves-has-exactly-kind-quality-england-side-needs/ |title=Harry Winks proves he has exactly the kind of quality this England side needs – sharp, self-assured and aggressive |first=Jason |last=Burt |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=15 October 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== Tottenham Hotspur manager Mauricio Pochettino has said "When we talk about midfielders – because you like to use Spanish midfielders like [[Xavi]] and [[Andrés Iniesta|(Andres) Iniesta]] – he's like this type of player",<ref name = "Winks Wonder">{{cite news |title=WINKS WONDER: Harry Winks ‘like Barcelona legends Andres Iniesta and Xavi’ but Mauricio Pochettino says Tottenham midfielder must focus on football |publisher=Talksport |date=14 September 2018 |accessdate=14 September 2018 |url=https://talksport.com/football/422282/tottenham-spurs-winks-iniesta-xavi-injury/}}</ref> describing Winks as "completely different to our other midfielders like [[Victor Wanyama]], [[Eric Dier]], [[Mousa Dembélé (Belgian footballer)|Mousa Dembélé]] and [[Moussa Sissoko]]. He has qualities to add to the team that are completely different".<ref name="unlock" /> ''[[Talksport]]'' remarked that following his breakthrough for club and country, Winks was "seen as a potential difference-maker for the Three Lions due to his very individual skill set", with Winks earning comparisons with foreign midfielders rather than his English contemporaries.<ref name="Winks Wonder" />
Ex-England and Spurs midfielder [[Danny Murphy (footballer, born 1977)|Danny Murphy]] said in September 2018 that the England team should be built around Winks, citing his performance for Tottenham against Real Madrid in the [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League group stage]] as evidence: "The one who I think has got the capability, more than anyone else I have seen, is [Harry] Winks. What he showed in that game in Madrid, in both games when he was fit and at it, was a confidence and an ability to play. To see the passes, to get his foot in and be disciplined and mix that mix of midfield talent that you need [...] for me, Winks is one of the best I've seen when he's at it – in terms of his all-round ability."<ref>{{cite news |title=TALENT: Tottenham Hotspur starlet Harry Winks can solve England's midfield problem, says former Liverpool man Danny Murphy |first=Joe |last=Coleman |date=10 September 2018 |accessdate=14 September 2018 |publisher=Talksport |url=https://talksport.com/football/420735/tottenham-hotspur-harry-winks-can-solve-englands-midfield-liverpool-danny-murphy/}}</ref> ''[[ESPN FC]]''{{'}}s Ben Pearce opined in 2018: "England are still missing a [[Playmaker#Deep-lying playmakers|deep-lying playmaker]] [...] Those wondering who could possibly fill the void have obviously forgotten Winks, who excels at keeping possession with quick, short passes".<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Winks ready to revitalise creaking Spurs midfield after long injury layoff |date=13 September 2018 |accessdate=14 September 2018 |first=Ben |last=Pearce |website=ESPN FC |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/tottenham-hotspur/367/blog/post/3631601/harry-winks-ready-to-revitalise-creaking-spurs-midfield-after-long-injury-layoff}}</ref>

{{short description|English association football player}} {{other people}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Harry Kane | image = Harry Kane in Russia 2.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Kane training with [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] | fullname = Harry Edward Kane<ref name=Hugman>{{Hugman|23634|accessdate=31 March 2016}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|7|28|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/harry-kane-230567/ |title=Harry Kane |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=6 December 2017}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Walthamstow]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref name=Profile>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/3960/Harry-Kane/overview |title=Harry Kane: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> | position = [[Striker (association football)|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = 1999–2001 | youthclubs1 = Ridgeway Rovers | youthyears2 = 2001–2002 | youthclubs2 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | youthyears3 = 2002–2004 | youthclubs3 = Ridgeway Rovers | youthyears4 = 2004 | youthclubs4 = [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] | youthyears5 = 2004–2010 | youthclubs5 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Reserves and Academy|Tottenham Hotspur]] | years1 = 2009– | clubs1 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps1 = 176 | goals1 = 125 | years2 = 2011 | clubs2 = → [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] (loan) | caps2 = 18 | goals2 = 5 | years3 = 2012 | clubs3 = → [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] (loan) | caps3 = 22 | goals3 = 7 | years4 = 2012–2013 | clubs4 = → [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] (loan) | caps4 = 3 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2013 | clubs5 = → [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] (loan) | caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2010 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2012 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 6 | nationalyears3 = 2013 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 14 | nationalgoals4 = 8 | nationalyears5 = 2015– | nationalteam5 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps5 = 36 | nationalgoals5 = 21 | club-update = 00:20, 23 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 00:20, 23 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Harry Edward Kane''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MBE}} (born 28 July 1993) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Striker (association football)|striker]] for {{English football updater|TottenhH}} club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[England national football team|England national team]]. Many panel members commissioned by ''[[The Guardian]]'' considered him to be one of the best players in the world in 2018.{{efn|A voting panel comprised 225 judges (coaches, broadcasters, reporters, correspondents, editors, and former players) from 69 countries (19 judges from Africa, 20 from Asia, 140 from Europe, 11 from North and Central America, and 35 from South America).}}<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/ng-interactive/2018/dec/18/the-100-best-male-footballers-in-the-world-2018-nos-100-71 |title=The 100 best male footballers in the world 2018 |website=[[TheGuardian.com]] |date=20 December 2018 |accessdate=13 January 2019}}</ref>
Born and raised in [[Walthamstow]], Kane began his professional career at Tottenham Hotspur, where, after fast progression through the team's youth academy, he was promoted to the senior team in 2009, at age 16. He did not initially feature for the side, and instead, was [[Loan (sports)|loan]]ed out several times to clubs across the [[English football league system|English football pyramid]], including [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]], [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].
Kane's involvement at Tottenham began to increase following the appointment of [[Mauricio Pochettino]] as head coach in 2014. In his [[2014–15 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|first full season]] at the club, Kane netted 31 goals across all competitions, and finished as the league's second highest goalscorer, winning the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] award. After the [[2015–16 Premier League|following campaign]], at age 23, Kane finished as league's [[List of top Premier League goal scorers by season#2015.E2.80.9316|top goalscorer]], and guided the club to [[UEFA Champions League]] qualification. In the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17 season]], Kane also completed the season as the league's top goalscorer, and helped the club finish as the competition's runners-up, while he won the [[PFA Fans' Player of the Year]] award. In the [[2017–18 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2017–18 season]], Kane registered his best campaign statistically to date, with 41 goals scored in 48 games in all competitions.
Kane holds the record for most [[Premier League Player of the Month]] awards (six; shared with [[Steven Gerrard]]) and has been selected for the [[PFA Team of the Year]] four times. He established himself as Tottenham's fourth [[List of Tottenham Hotspur F.C. records and statistics#Top 10 all-time scorers|all-time scorer]] in official competitions in January 2019, and holds the [[List of Premier League players with 100 or more goals|best strike-rate]] (0.70 goals per game) in Premier League history.
An English international, Kane has scored 20 goals in 35 games for his country. He has appeared and scored at every youth level, and made his senior debut in March 2015 at age 22, where he scored on his debut. Kane featured and scored at [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]], before he was selected as the squad's captain from May 2018, prior to the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]. In the tournament, Kane led England to fourth-place, their highest finish since 1990, by finishing as the top goalscorer, and won the [[FIFA World Cup awards|Golden Boot]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44840817 |title=World Cup 2018: Harry Kane wins Golden Boot |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 July 2018 |accessdate=15 July 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Harry Edward Kane was born in [[Walthamstow]], London to Kim and Patrick Kane and has one older brother, Charlie.<ref name=tottenhamhotspur>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/first-team-squad/harry-kane/ |title=Harry Kane |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref><ref name=jim/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/one-day-ill-play-for-england-london-schoolboys-dream-is-about-to-come-true-10138435.html |title=One day I'll play for England: London schoolboy's dream is about to come true |first=John |last=Dunne |newspaper=London Evening Standard |date=27 March 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> He has Irish ancestry through his father who is from [[Galway]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.irishpost.com/sport/5-things-never-knew-harry-kanes-surprising-irish-roots-156293 |title=5 things you never knew about Harry Kane's surprising Irish roots |last=Beresford |first=Jack |newspaper=The Irish Post |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref><ref name="galway">{{cite news |url=http://www.the42.ie/harry-kane-england-2001121-Mar2015/ |publisher=The 42 |title=Let's forget about Harry Kane for Ireland, he's after getting an England call-up |date=28 March 2015}}</ref> The family moved to [[Chingford]] where he attended Larkswood Primary Academy until 2004,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/news/13424088.New_sporting_talent_unearthed_at_Harry_Kane_s_primary_school/ |title=New sporting talent unearthed at Harry Kane's primary school |first=Natalie |last=Glanvill |newspaper=East London and West Sussex Guardian |date=16 July 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://larkswoodlime.london/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/NEWSLETTER-WB-16th-Feb-2015.pdf |title=Larkswood Primary Academy Newsletter |date=9 February 2015 |access-date=1 October 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002022012/http://larkswoodlime.london/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/NEWSLETTER-WB-16th-Feb-2015.pdf |archive-date=2 October 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> followed by [[Chingford Foundation School]] (also attended by [[David Beckham]]).<ref>{{cite web |title=Hall of Fame |url=https://chingfordpedept.wordpress.com/hall-of-fame |website=Chingford Foundation School PE Department |accessdate=3 May 2017}}</ref> He played football from a young age, joining a local club, Ridgeway Rovers, when he was six in 1999.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44625669 |title=World Cup 2018: Harry Kane – the making of England & Tottenham striker |date=2 July 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Kane talked about footballing in the family:
{{cquote|I think the sporting genes come from my Mum's side of the family although the topic is a hot debate in the Kane household. Dad probably won't like me saying that, but I think my granddad Eric on my Mum's side was quite a good footballer, and played at a decent level.<ref name="worrall 2">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT7&lpg=PT7#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref>}}
Kane also said: "Most of my family were Spurs fans and I grew up 15 minutes from the ground, so I was always going to be a Spurs fan".<ref name="worrall 2"/> He named former Spurs striker [[Teddy Sheringham]] his childhood idol, and saw him as a "great finisher" and a role model in his ability to get in the [[penalty area|box]] and score goals.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/harry-kane-teddy-sheringham-has-been-a-great-role-model-for-me-9285534.html |title=Harry Kane: Teddy Sheringham has been a great role model for me |first=Simon |last=Peach |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=25 April 2014 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Other childhood sporting influences he cited include David Beckham and [[Jermain Defoe]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2015/05/20/kanes-childhood-heroes-consisted-of-sheringham-beckham-and-d/ |title=Tottenham striker Harry Kane's childhood heroes consisted of Sheringham, Beckham and Defoe |first=Dale |last=O'Donnell |website=HITC |date=20 May 2015 |accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref> Kane has also spoken of his admiration for the former Brazil forward [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]], adding that he loved to watch footage of him on [[YouTube]]: "He was one of the first ones I looked at and thought, 'Wow. He's a goalscorer, I want to be a goalscorer.'"<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: I love to watch Brazilian Ronaldo on YouTube |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/11397284/harry-kane-i-love-to-watch-brazilian-ronaldo-on-youtube |accessdate=29 August 2018 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Tottenham Hotspur=== ====Youth career==== Kane first played for a local club, Ridgeway Rovers, and joined the [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] youth academy when he was eight years old. He was released after one season for being "a bit chubby" and not "very athletic", according to [[Liam Brady]] who was then in charge of Arsenal's academy.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/02/12/liam-brady-arsenal-released-harry-kane-bit-chubby/ |title=Liam Brady: Arsenal released Harry Kane because he was 'a bit chubby' |first=Daniel |last=Zeqiri |date=12 February 2018 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> Manager [[Arsène Wenger]] stated in November 2015 that he was disappointed that Arsenal chose to release Kane.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hytner |first=David |title=Arsène Wenger: I was angry when I found out Arsenal had let Harry Kane go |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/nov/06/arsene-wenger-arsenal-tottenham-harry-kane |accessdate=8 November 2015 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=6 November 2015}}</ref> He also had a trial at [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] but was not initially successful,<ref name=worrall>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT9&lpg=PT9#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref> and he returned to his old club Ridgeway Rovers. In 2004, at the age of eleven, he joined [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] academy for a four to six-week trial, and was then given another chance at Tottenham after he impressed playing for Watford against Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |title=Record-breaking Kane proves that Watford's loss was Tottenham's emphatic gain |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/12070870/Record-breaking-Kane-proves-that-Watfords-loss-was-Tottenhams-emphatic-gain.html |first=Gerry |last=Cox |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=27 December 2015 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/tottenhams-harry-kane-reveals-how-1169044 |title=Tottenham's Harry Kane reveals how Watford helped catapult him to stardom |first=Tom |last=Moore |date=5 February 2018 |newspaper=Herfordshire Mercury |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref> He first played at Tottenham as a [[midfielder]] – initially in a holding position, then as an attacking midfielder.<ref name=worrall/> In his early days at the club, he did not stand out as a player as he was not big nor was he particularly quick, but those who worked with him at the club noted his constant desire to improve various aspects of his game.<ref name=jim/> In the [[2008–09 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2008–09 season]], he played in the under-16s side that competed in the Copa Chivas tournament in Mexico, and the Bellinzona tournament in Switzerland, scoring three goals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Unearth themselves a striking gem |url=http://www.footballfancast.com/football-blogs/harry-kane-tottenham-unearth-themselves-a-striking-gem |publisher=Footballfancast |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> In July 2009, on his 16th birthday, he signed a scholarship contract with Tottenham.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VH2pDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT10&lpg=PT10#v=onepage |title=Harry Kane – The Biography |first=Frank |last=Worrall |isbn=9781786065384 |chapter=Chapter 1: Beginnings |publisher=John Blake Publishing Ltd |date=18 May 2017}}</ref>
In the [[2009–10 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2009–10 season]], Kane played 22 times for Tottenham's under-18s, scoring 18 goals.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.footballfancast.com/2010/09/football-blogs/harry-kane-tottenham-unearth-themselves-a-striking-gem |title=Tottenham unearth themselves a striking gem |date=10 September 2010 |publisher=FootballFanCast.com}}</ref> Kane appeared on the first-team bench twice during the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite web |title=Tottenham: Results/matches: 2009/10 |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2590&teamTabs=results&season_id=139 |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> Both matches were in home domestic cup victories: one the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] fixture against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 27 October 2009<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham 2–0 Everton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8323083.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 October 2009}}</ref> and the other in the [[FA Cup]] fourth-round [[replay (sports)|replay]] against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 24 February 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=Roopanarine |first=Les |title=Tottenham 4–0 Bolton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8528819.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 February 2010}}</ref> He signed his first professional contract with the club in July 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=Kane in O's loan |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/kane-in-os-loan-070111/ |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |date=7 January 2011 |accessdate=31 March 2016}}</ref>
====2010–14: Loan spells across England==== On 7 January 2011, Kane moved to [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] until the end of the [[2010–11 Leyton Orient F.C. season|2010–11 season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/leyton_orient/9349908.stm |title=Leyton Orient sign Harry Kane & Andrew Whing |date=7 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Manager [[Russell Slade]] was "happy" at his arrival and said, "I'm sure he will have an impact with us over the coming months".<ref name=Harry>{{cite web |title=From Leyton Orient to Tottenham's first team via Millwall: Charting the rise of Harry Kane |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11660/9734189/from-leyton-orient-to-tottenhams-first-team-via-millwall-charting-the-rise-of-harry-kane |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> He made his first-team debut for Orient on 15 January, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Scott McGleish]] in the 73rd minute of a 1–1 draw away to [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9359393.stm#blq-nav |title=Rochdale 1–1 Leyton Orient |date=15 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> A week later, Kane scored his first first-team goal against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]; making his first-ever start, "unmarked" Kane scored from a [[Dean Cox (English footballer)|Dean Cox]] freekick in the 57th minute as Orient eventually won 4–0.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9362036.stm |title=Leyton Orient 4–0 Sheffield Wednesday |date=22 January 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Four-star Orient stun Owls |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/leyton-or-vs-sheff-wed/report/216323 |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref> Slade said that he was "delighted" that Kane scored a goal on his first league start.<ref name=Harry/> On 12 February, he scored twice in a 4–1 win over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]], after coming on as a substitute for McGleish in the 70th minute.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9387845.stm |title=Leyton Orient 4–1 Bristol Rovers |date=12 February 2011 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He ended the season scoring five goals in 18 matches.<ref name=Kane>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane timeline: How has the Spurs starlet gone from peripheral figure to England goalscorer? |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/harry-kane-timeline-how-spurs-5405662 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
On 25 August 2011, Kane made his first appearance for Tottenham, starting in the second leg of their [[UEFA Europa League]] qualification round against [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]], with Tottenham making changes after winning the first leg 5–0. His debut was a goalless match, although he won a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] after being fouled by goalkeeper [[Jamie MacDonald (footballer)|Jamie MacDonald]], who then saved the penalty which Kane took himself.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lyon |first=Sam |title=Tottenham 0–0 Hearts |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/14569541.stm |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2011}}</ref> He went on to make six appearances in the Europa League [[2011–12 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|that season]], scoring his first Tottenham goal in the 4–0 win away to [[Shamrock Rovers F.C.|Shamrock Rovers]] on 15 December 2011.<ref>{{cite news |last=Higginson |first=Marc |title=Shamrock Rovers 0–4 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16081794 |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2011}}</ref>
On 29 December 2011, Kane and Tottenham teammate [[Ryan Mason]] agreed to join [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on loan from 1 January 2012 until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Millwall agree loans for Tottenham's Ryan Mason and Harry Kane |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/16358540 |accessdate=11 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 December 2011}}</ref> After making his debut against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], manager [[Kenny Jackett]] said that he had "very good debut" but was "unlucky not to score". He also said that Kane would "be a good addition" for the club in the second half of the season. He went on to score seven goals in the final 14 matches of the season.<ref name=Harry/> Kane scored nine goals in 27 matches which resulted in him being named Millwall's Young Player of the Year for [[2011–12 Millwall F.C. season|2011–12]].<ref name=YPOTY>{{cite web |first=Jay |last=Taylor |title=Millwall boss Jackett hands award to Spurs loanee Kane |url=http://www.newsatden.co.uk/2612-millwall-boss-jackett-hands-award-to-spurs-loanee-kane.html |website=News at Den |date=27 April 2012 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref> His run of goals scored towards the end of the season has been credited with helping to raise Millwall in the table away from the threat of relegation that season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/09/harry-kane-loan-millwall-tottenham-fa-cup |title=How Harry Kane's loan saved Millwall from relegation and made him a man |first=David |last=Hytner |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=9 March 2017 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref>
Kane spent pre-season 2012–13 season with Tottenham, scoring a [[Hat-trick#Association football|hat-trick]] in a 6–0 away win against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on 10 August 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.southendunited.co.uk/news/article/100812-southend-0-tottenham-xi-6-306078.aspx |title=Southend United finished pre-season with an embarrassing 6–0 defeat to a Tottenham Hotspur XI at Roots Hall on Friday night |publisher=Southend United F.C. |date=10 August 2012 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> On 18 August, he made his [[2012–13 Premier League|Premier League]] debut, against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/261565/report |title=Losing start for Villas-Boas |publisher=Sky Sports |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> Coming as an 86th-minute substitute for [[Sandro (footballer, born 1989)|Sandro]], Tottenham lost the match 2–1.<ref name=Harry/>
On 31 August 2012, Kane joined Premier League team [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on a season-long loan,<ref>{{cite web |title=From Leyton Orient to Tottenham's first team via Millwall: Charting the rise of Harry Kane |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11660/9734189/from-leyton-orient-to-tottenhams-first-team-via-millwall-charting-the-rise-of-harry-kane |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> making his debut as a substitute against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/19528011 |last=Smallwood |first=Jimmy |title=Norwich 0–0 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 September 2012 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref> Kane suffered an injury, breaking a [[metatarsal bone]], in the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]] in only his second appearance.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/foot-fracture-for-kane-28868527.html |title=Foot fracture for Kane |newspaper=Belfast Telegraph |date=28 September 2012 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> The 19-year-old underwent his rehabilitation at Tottenham but returned to action for Norwich on 29 December 2012, coming off the bench at half time as Norwich lost 3–4 to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eveningnews24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city/photo-gallery-defeat-to-manchester-city-sees-norwich-city-end-2012-where-they-began-1-1756832 |title=Photo gallery: Defeat to Manchester City sees Norwich City end 2012 where they began |first=David |last=Cuffley |newspaper=Norwich Evening News |date=31 December 2012 |accessdate=2 February 2018}}</ref> However, with Tottenham having been unable to add to their attacking options during the January transfer window, they opted to recall Kane on 1 February 2013, four months before he was due to return.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/tottenham-recall-striker-harry-kane-from-norwich-8477308.html |title=Tottenham recall striker Harry Kane from Norwich |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=1 February 2013 |accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
Twenty days after he was recalled to Tottenham, Kane joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for the remainder of the season to aid in the club's push for automatic promotion from the Championship.<ref>{{cite news |title=Harry Kane: Leicester City sign Tottenham striker |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21533301 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 May 2013 |date=21 February 2013}}</ref> He marked his home debut with a goal against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], in a 3–0 win on 26 February 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/feb/26/leicester-city-blackburn-rovers-championship |title=Resurgent Leicester City punish lacklustre Blackburn Rovers |first=Richard |last=Rae |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=26 February 2013 |accessdate=19 June 2018}}</ref> He made 13 appearances for the [[East Midlands]] club, eight from the bench, and they reached [[2013 Football League play-offs#Champonship|the play-off semi-final]] before being eliminated by Watford.<ref>{{cite web |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Watford 3–1 Leicester (agg 3 – 2) |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/22417772 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref>
Kane scored his first Tottenham goal of the 2013–14 season at [[White Hart Lane]] in a [[2013–14 Football League Cup|League Cup]] tie against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], scoring the equaliser in extra time, the match finished 2–2.<ref name="Hull City League Cup">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24633791 |title=Tottenham 2–2 Hull (8–7 on pens) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 October 2013 |accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> Tottenham won 8–7 on [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties]], with Kane taking and converting the fifth of the nine sets of spot-kicks.<ref name="Hull City League Cup"/>
