{{Use British English|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Eric Dier | image = Eric Dier 2018-06-28 1.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Dier playing for [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] | fullname = Eric Jeremy Edgar Dier<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tournament.fifadata.com/documents/FWC/2018/pdf/FWC_2018_SQUADLISTS.PDF |title=FIFA World Cup Russia 2018: List of players: England |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=10 |date=15 July 2018 |accessdate=12 October 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|1|15|df=y}}<ref>{{Hugman|26595|accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Cheltenham]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/4112/Eric-Dier/overview |title=Eric Dier: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=10 December 2017}}</ref> | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] / [[Defensive midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | clubnumber = 15 | youthyears1 = 2003–2012 | youthclubs1 = [[Sporting CP]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs2 = → [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] (loan) | years1 = 2012–2014 | clubs1 = [[Sporting CP B]] | caps1 = 16 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2012–2014 | clubs2 = [[Sporting CP]] | caps2 = 27 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2014– | clubs3 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps3 = 151 | goals3 = 9 | nationalyears1 = 2011 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 8 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2013–2014 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 6 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 9 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2015– | nationalteam5 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps5 = 39 | nationalgoals5 = 3 | club-update = 00:07, 23 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 00:07, 23 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Eric Jeremy Edgar Dier''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|aɪər}} {{respell|DIRE}};<ref>{{Citation |last=Tottenham Hotspur |title=Dizzy Baseball Challenge FT Eric Dier + Daniel Murphy |date=9 February 2016 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cu7QBYK4fA8&t=2s |accessdate=18 November 2017}}</ref> born 15 January 1994) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for {{English football updater|TottenhH}} club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and the [[England national football team|England national team]]. A versatile defensive player, Dier has been deployed as a [[defensive midfielder]], a [[centre back]] and a [[right back]].
Dier grew up in Portugal, where he came through the youth ranks at [[Sporting CP]], making his [[Sporting CP B|reserve]] and senior debuts in 2012 after a [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]. In 2014, he moved to Tottenham Hotspur on a five-year contract for a fee of £4 million.
Despite interest from Portugal, Dier opted to represent England in international football. He made his debut for the senior team in November 2015, and was chosen for [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and the [[FIFA World Cup 2018|2018 World Cup]].
==Early and personal life== Born in [[Cheltenham]], Gloucestershire, Dier moved to Portugal from England when he was seven years old,<ref>{{cite news |title=Dier on growing up at Sporting Lisbon |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34606989 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 October 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> when his mother was offered a job running the hospitality programme at [[UEFA Euro 2004]].<ref name="theguardian.com"/><ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham: Eric Dier joins Spurs from Sporting on five-year deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28597872 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> With his parents and five siblings, Dier spent a year living in the [[Algarve]] region before moving to [[Lisbon]]. In 2010, his parents returned to England while Dier remained in Portugal, living at [[Sporting C.P. Youth and Academy|Sporting CP's academy]].<ref name="algarveresident">{{cite web |last=Wright |first=Chris |title=Sporting youngster helps to launch new Umbro England |url=http://portugalresident.com/sporting-lisbon-youngster-helps-to-launch-new-umbro-england |publisher=Portugal Resident |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=22 October 2010}}</ref>
Dier is the grandson of [[Ted Croker]], a former secretary of [[The Football Association]] (FA) and president of [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]], and great-nephew of [[Peter Croker]], who both played professionally for [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. His father, Jeremy, is a former professional tennis player.<ref name="skysports-scout">{{cite news |title=Sky Sports Scout – Eric Dier |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/transfers/scout/0,24035,15198_6091891,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=20 January 2011 |date=22 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100501123631/http://www.skysports.com/football/transfers/scout/0,24035,15198_6091891,00.html |archivedate=1 May 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Early career=== While playing football at the International Preparatory School in Lisbon, Dier's footballing ability was spotted by his P.E. teacher Miguel Silva, who referred him to Sporting's scouts at the age of eight.<ref name="dailymail"/>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2018}} Dier signed professional terms with Sporting in April 2010. The Portuguese club beat [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] to his signature.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sport.co.uk/news/Football/36629/Sporting_beat_off_competition_to_sign_English_wonderkid.aspx |title=Sporting beat off competition to sign English wonderkid |first=Nigel |last=Brown |publisher=Sport.co.uk |date=8 April 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411223334/http://www.sport.co.uk/news/Football/36629/Sporting_beat_off_competition_to_sign_English_wonderkid.aspx |archivedate=11 April 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Sporting also sold 50% economic rights of the player to a third-party owner, [[Quality Sports Investments|Quality Football Ireland Limited]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi2004/emitentes/docs/PCS31990.pdf |title=Sporting Clube de Portugal – Futebol SAD publishes the Report and Financial Statements for the 1H2010/2011 |date=28 February 2011 |accessdate=8 April 2011 |publisher=Sporting CP |language=Portuguese |format=PDF}}</ref> Sporting bought Dier back in February 2012 by selling 50% rights of [[Filipe Chaby]].
In January 2011, Dier agreed to join [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] until 30 June. Sporting CP's official website stated that the loan was "an opportunity for the athlete to grow in a more competitive and demanding environment".<ref name="sportingcp">{{cite web |title=Eric Dier emprestado |url=http://www.sporting.pt/Noticias/Futebol/Fut_Form/notfutform_futericdieremprestado_200111_70977.asp |publisher=Sporting CP |accessdate=20 January 2011 |language=Portuguese |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110122202939/http://www.sporting.pt/Noticias/Futebol/Fut_Form/notfutform_futericdieremprestado_200111_70977.asp |archivedate=22 January 2011}}</ref><ref name=evertonfc>{{cite web |last=Griffiths |first=Darren |title=Teenager joins academy |url=http://www.evertonfc.com//news/archive/2011/01/20/teenager-joins-academy |publisher=Everton F.C. |accessdate=21 January 2011 |date=21 January 2011}}</ref> Dier represented Everton U18s ten times during his loan spell and won the 2010–11 U18 Premier League with the team.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rea |first=Alex |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/evertons-u18-premier-league-champions-7169857 |title=Everton's U18 Premier League champions of 2010/11: where are they now? |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=25 May 2014 |accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref> Dier encountered difficulties resettling into English life, but in the summer of 2011, he extended his loan stay in the Everton academy for an additional 12 months.<ref name="theguardian.com">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/oct/23/tottenham-eric-dier-interview |title=Tottenham's Eric Dier: Some people forget I'm essentially a foreign player | Football |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=21 May 2014 |accessdate=1 April 2016}}</ref>
===Breakthrough at Sporting=== On 26 August 2012, Dier made his debut with [[Sporting CP B|Sporting B]] in a [[2012–13 Segunda Liga]] 3–1 away win against [[Atlético Clube de Portugal|Atlético]], replacing [[Diego Rubio]] in the 77th minute.<ref>{{cite news |date=26 August 2012 |language=Portuguese |title=Atlético 1–3 Sporting B |url=http://www.lpfp.pt/segunda_liga/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=4&jogo=7641 |publisher=Liga Portuguesa de Futebol Profissional |accessdate=5 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911013659/http://lpfp.pt/segunda_liga/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=4&jogo=7641 |archivedate=11 September 2012}}</ref> On 4 November 2012, Dier scored his first senior goal with a direct free kick against [[S.L. Benfica B|Benfica B]] in a 3–1 away win in the [[LigaPro|Segunda Liga]].<ref>{{cite news |date=4 November 2012 |language=Portuguese |title=Benfica B-Sporting B, 1–3 |url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/liga_honra/interior.aspx?content_id=786654 |newspaper=Jornal Record |accessdate=5 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826120400/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/liga_honra/interior.aspx?content_id=786654 |archivedate=26 August 2014 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 11 November 2012, Dier was called to play for the first team in a [[2012–13 Primeira Liga|Primeira Liga]] 1–0 home win against [[S.C. Braga|Braga]], assisting [[Ricky van Wolfswinkel]] for the match's only goal.<ref>{{cite news |date=11 November 2012 |language=Portuguese |title=Sporting 1–0 Braga |url=http://www.lpfp.pt/liga_zon_sagres/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=9&jogo=7461 |publisher=Liga Portuguesa de Futebol Profissional |accessdate=11 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121109164510/http://www.lpfp.pt/liga_zon_sagres/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=9&jogo=7461 |archivedate=9 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=11 November 2012 |language=Portuguese |title=Sporting 1–0 SC Braga |url=http://www.zerozero.pt/jogo.php?id=2256593 |publisher=Zerozero |accessdate=11 November 2012}}</ref> Fifteen days later, he scored his first goal for Sporting's first squad in a 2–2 league away draw against [[Moreirense F.C.|Moreirense]].<ref>{{cite news |date=26 November 2012 |language=Portuguese |title=Moreirense 2–2 Sporting |url=http://www.lpfp.pt/liga_zon_sagres/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=10&jogo=7487 |publisher=Liga Portuguesa de Futebol Profissional |accessdate=11 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120712180634/http://www.lpfp.pt/liga_zon_sagres/pages/jogo.aspx?epoca=20122013&jornada=10&jogo=7487 |archivedate=12 July 2012}}</ref>
===Tottenham Hotspur=== [[File:Eric Dier 01-03-2015 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Dier playing for [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]]]]
On 2 August 2014, Dier signed a five-year contract with Tottenham Hotspur in a £4 million transfer.<ref>{{cite news |title=Transfer news: Eric Dier completes move to Spurs on five-year deal |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9403944? |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=2 August 2014 |date=2 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Spurs sign Eric Dier from Sporting |url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/story/1970164/tottenham-sign-england-under-21-defender-eric-dier-from-sporting? |publisher=ESPN FC |accessdate=2 August 2014 |date=2 August 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut for the club on the first day of the [[2014–15 Premier League]] season away to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] on 16 August, and scored the only goal of the match in added time.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rose |first=Gary |title=West Ham United 0–1 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/28718387 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Eight days later, in his second match and in his [[White Hart Lane]] debut, he headed in a corner from [[Erik Lamela]] in an eventual 4–0 win over newly promoted [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Fifield |first=Dominic |title=Tottenham give Harry Redknapp unhappy homecoming with QPR defeat |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/24/tottenham-qpr-premier-league-match-report |accessdate=24 August 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=24 August 2014}}</ref> Dier started on 1 March 2015 as Tottenham lost the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]] to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref>
Dier signed a new contract on 9 September 2015, lasting until 2020.<ref>{{cite news |title=Eric Dier: Tottenham defender signs new contract until 2020 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34203282 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 September 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> During the [[2015–16 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2015–16 season]], he was utilised as a defensive midfielder by Tottenham head coach [[Mauricio Pochettino]],<ref name=int/> establishing himself as the regular partner to [[Mousa Dembélé (Belgian footballer)|Mousa Dembélé]] as Tottenham challenged eventual champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] for the [[List of English football champions|Premier League title]].<ref name='strange'>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/10/eric-dier-strange-start-tottenham-hotspur-manchester-united |title=Eric Dier ready to put his strange start to the season for Tottenham behind him |date=11 December 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}}</ref> On 15 August, he scored Tottenham's first goal of the [[2015–16 Premier League|Premier League]] season in a 2–2 draw at home to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], and on 26 September, Dier scored the team's equalising goal in a 4–1 home victory over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Mandeep |last=Sanghera |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34299624 |title=Tottenham Hotspur 4–1 Manchester City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 13 September 2016, Dier signed a new five-year contract to last until 2021.<ref>{{cite news |title=Eric Dier: Tottenham midfielder signs new five-year contract |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37347484 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
During the [[2016–17 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2016–17]] season, Dier returned to the centre-back position due to Tottenham's acquisition of defensive midfielder [[Victor Wanyama]] and injuries to defenders [[Toby Alderweireld]] and [[Jan Vertonghen]].<ref name='strange'/> He made his [[UEFA Champions League]] debut in a 2–1 loss to [[AS Monaco FC]] in Tottenham's opening [[2016–17 UEFA Champions League group stage|group]] match at Wembley Stadium.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2017/clubs/player=250050416/profile/index.html |title=Eric Dier |accessdate=2 April 2017 |publisher=UEFA}}</ref> On 25 October 2016, Dier [[Captain (association football)|captained]] Tottenham for the first time in a 2–1 loss to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] in the fourth round of the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/10/25/liverpool-vs-spurs-efl-cup-fourth-round---live-updates/ |title=Liverpool 2 Spurs 1: Sturridge scores two as Reds survive late Tottenham push to go through to last eight |date=25 October 2016 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref> He was also given the captain's armband for the 3rd and 4th round [[2016–17 FA Cup|FA Cup]] ties against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] respectively.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2017-01-09/dier-being-spurs-captain-would-be-an-honour/ |title=Dier: Being Spurs captain would be an honour |date=9 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/tottenham-vs-wycombe-team-news-heungmin-son-leads-the-line-as-eric-dier-named-captain-a3452236.html |title=Tottenham vs Wycombe team news: Heung-min Son leads the line as Eric Dier named captain |date=28 January 2017 |newspaper=London Evening Standard}}</ref> On 1 April 2017, Dier scored his first goal of 2016–17 in a 2–0 win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/04/01/burnley-0-tottenham-2-eric-diers-goal-sends-spurs-way-back-title/ |title=Burnley 0 Tottenham 2: Eric Dier's goal sends Spurs on their way back into title picture |date=1 April 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref>
In the [[2018–19 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2018–19 season]], Dier scored his first goal of the season, which is his first in 18 months, in the 1–0 win against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], helping Tottenham to their joint best start of a season in the Premier League after eight games.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/tottenham-cardiff-city-premier-league-match-report-a8571971.html |title=Tottenham vs Cardiff: Eric Dier's early goal sees off 10-man Cardiff City |first=Darren |last=Witcoop |date=6 October 2018 |work=The Independent}}</ref> He underwent surgery mid-December 2018 due to [[appendicitis]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/dec/16/tottenham-eric-dier-appendix |title=Tottenham’s Eric Dier ruled out until 2019 after surgery to remove appendix |date=16 December 2018 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> and returned to the team on 20 January 2019, coming on as a substitute in the game against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/20/fulham-vs-tottenham-premier-league-live-score-latest-updates/ |title=Harry Winks breaks Fulham hearts with last minute winner but Dele Alli adds to Spurs' injury concerns |first1=Jason |last1=Burt|first2= JJ |last2=Bull|date=20 January 2019 }}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== [[File:Eric Dier (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Dier playing for [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] in 2012]] Dier had been approached by the [[Portuguese Football Federation]] to play for Portugal in the future, but could only do so once he turned 18.<ref name="umbro"/> He had been involved in a high-profile [[England national football team|England national team]] kit promotion for sportswear manufacturers [[Umbro]], and his appearance in the campaign prompted British newspaper ''[[Daily Mail]]'' to question why The Football Association had not contacted him with a view for playing in their youth national teams.<ref name="dailymail">{{cite news |last=Kay |first=Alex |title=Eric Dier was called up by Umbro to star with Rooney & Co in this shoot. He is the rising star of Sporting Lisbon... so why haven't the FA been in touch? |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1318330/Eric-Dier-rising-star-Sporting-Lisbon--havent-FA-touch.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=20 January 2011 |accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2018}}<ref name="umbro">{{cite web |title=The New Fabric of England: Eric Dier |url=http://blog.umbro.com/post/the-new-fabric-of-england-eric-dier/ |publisher=Umbro |accessdate=20 January 2011}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Upon his signing for Everton, an FA spokesman said, "Our intention will be to select him for the youth squad in the coming weeks," referring to the 2011 edition of the under-17 international Algarve Tournament.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news |last=Winter |first=Henry |title=Everton sign Sporting Lisbon youngster Eric Dier on loan as England close in on his services |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/everton/8272833/Everton-sign-Sporting-Lisbon-youngster-Eric-Dier-on-loan-as-England-close-in-on-his-services.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=21 January 2011 |date=20 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
Dier earned his first England call-up in November 2011 when [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] head coach [[Noel Blake]] picked him for a match against Slovakia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/D/eric-dier.aspx |title=Eric Dier |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref> He played the full 90 minutes in the 1–1 draw on 16 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u18s/News/match-centre/2011/SlovakiavEngland |title=Slovakia vs England |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 November 2011 |accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref>
On 28 May 2013, he was named in manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer, born 1953)|Peter Taylor]]'s 21-man squad for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/u20s-world-cup-squad-announcement-280513 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615071407/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/u20s-world-cup-squad-announcement-280513 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=15 June 2013 |title=Final squad named |publisher=The Football Association |date=28 May 2013 |accessdate=5 December 2013}}</ref> He made his debut on 16 June in a 3–0 win in a warm-up match against [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130624222816/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 |dead-url=yes |archivedate=24 June 2013 |title=Training win for Three Lions |publisher=The Football Association |date=16 June 2013 |accessdate=5 December 2013 |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers}}</ref>
Dier made his debut for the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21s]] on 13 August 2013 in a 6–0 win against [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/23690472 |title=England Under-21s thrash Scotland 6–0 in friendly |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> In 2014, he pulled out of the squad, informing manager [[Gareth Southgate]] that he did not want to be deployed as a right back anymore and would rather work on the centre-back position at his club, Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham centre-half Eric Dier opts out of England Under-21 duty to train with Premier League paymasters |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/11227479/Tottenham-centre-half-Eric-Dier-opts-out-of-England-Under-21-duty-to-train-with-Premier-League-paymasters.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London}}</ref>
===Senior=== [[File:Eric Dier 2018-06-28 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Dier playing for [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]] On 5 November 2015, Dier was selected for the first time to the England senior team by manager [[Roy Hodgson]] ahead of friendlies against [[Spain national football team|Spain]] and [[France national football team|France]].<ref name=int>{{cite news |title=Eric Dier in England squad for Spain and France friendlies |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34736737 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 November 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> He made his debut eight days later against the former at [[Alicante]]'s [[Estadio José Rico Pérez]] as a 63rd-minute substitute alongside his Tottenham teammate Dele Alli in a 2–0 loss.<ref>{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Spain 2–0 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/34742149 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 November 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Dier made his first start on 17 November against France, a 2–0 win at Wembley, and his performance was highlighted by former international midfielder [[Jamie Redknapp]].<ref name=redknapp>{{cite news |last=Redknapp |first=Jamie |title=Eric Dier is the biggest England surprise and Wayne Rooney has lost none of his aura among the squad |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3322867/England-s-biggest-surprise-Eric-Dier-Wayne-Rooney-lost-none-aura-squad.html |accessdate=18 November 2015 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=18 November 2015}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=July 2018}} On 26 March 2016, he scored his first international goal, heading [[Jordan Henderson]]'s corner for the winner in a 3–2 victory against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in Berlin.<ref name="Germany 2–3 England">{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Germany 2–3 England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35849556 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 March 2016 |accessdate=28 March 2016}}</ref>
Dier was chosen for [[UEFA Euro 2016]] in France. In England's opening match against [[Russia national football team|Russia]] at the [[Stade Vélodrome]], he opened the scoring in the 1–1 draw through a direct free-kick.<ref>{{cite news |title=England 1–1 Russia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36450648 |accessdate=11 June 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 June 2016}}</ref>
On 10 November 2017, Dier captained the England team for the first time in a friendly match against Germany at Wembley that ended in a goalless draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/england-vs-germany-team-news-eric-dier-captain-gareth-southgate-a8047236.html |title=Tottenham's Eric Dier to captain England for friendly against Germany |date=9 November 2017 |newspaper=The Independent}}</ref>
He was named in the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref> and captained the squad in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup Group G#England vs Belgium|final group stage match against Belgium]]. Dier scored the decisive penalty in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Colombia vs England|second round match against Colombia]], giving England its first ever World Cup shootout victory and first competitive shootout victory since [[UEFA Euro 1996|Euro 96]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/england-vs-colombia-penalty-shootout-who-scored-kane-goal-video-watch-eric-dier-a8429861.html |title=Who scored as England beat Colombia on penalties |work=The Independent |accessdate=4 July 2018 |language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Style of play== Dier is a versatile player, who can play as a midfielder, centre back and right back.<ref name="independent"/> It has been noted that his versatility enabled Tottenham's effective adoption of a flexible approach, allowing them to switch system efficiently within a single match.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2017/may/01/eric-dier-versatility-tottenham-flexibility-arsenal |title=Eric Dier's versatility the basis of Tottenham's exquisite flexibility |first=Michael |last=Cox |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 May 2017}}</ref> He has decent pace, good heading and good mentality. Dier has said that he has mixed Portuguese and English style for his own.<ref name="independent">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/eric-dier-exclusive-i-am-english-but-i-m-like-any-other-foreigner-says-tottenham-centre-back-10253947.html |date=15 May 2015 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |title=Eric Dier exclusive: 'I am English but I'm like any other foreigner,' says Tottenham centre-back}}</ref> Another string to his bow is his fine free-kick taking.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/everything-you-need-know-about-spurs-new-boy-eric-dier#ruY3RfZWrwsqkuc5.99 |title=Everything you need to know about Spurs new boy Eric Dier |magazine=FourFourTwo |date=1 August 2014}}</ref> In 2018, [[ESPN]]'s Mark Ogden described Dier as "more of a destroyer than a creator".<ref>{{cite news |title=England must make World Cup run the start of something big, not another false dawn |work=ESPN |first=Mark |last=Ogden |accessdate=12 July 2018 |date=12 July 2018 |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/team/england/448/blog/post/3563230/england-must-make-world-cup-run-the-start-of-something-big-not-another-false-dawn?src=com}}</ref> Dier's idols are [[Roy Keane]] and [[Rafael Márquez]], who have inspired his playing style.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham's Eric Dier reveals Manchester United legend Roy Keane as one of his idols |url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/06/21/tottenhams-eric-dier-reveals-manchester-united-legend-roy-keane-as-one-of-his-idols-5958182/ |newspaper=Metro |location=London |date=21 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/european-championship/story/2899511/englands-eric-dier-eyes-reunion-with-portugal-stars-at-euro-2016 |title=England's Eric Dier eyes reunion with Portugal stars at Euro 2016 |publisher=ESPN FC |date=23 June 2016}}</ref>

{{Distinguish|Kyle Walker-Peters}} {{Use British English|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Kyle Walker | image = Kyle Walker.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Walker during training with [[England national football team|England]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] | fullname = Kyle Andrew Walker<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=11 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|5|28|df=y}}<ref name=Hugman1011>{{cite book |editor-first=Barry J. |editor-last=Hugman |title=The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2010–11 |year=2010 |publisher=Mainstream Publishing |location=Edinburgh |isbn=978-1-84596-601-0 |page=426}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Sheffield]], England | height = {{convert|1.78|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/kyle-walker/68532/ |title=K. Walker: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=15 May 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Right back]] | currentclub = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | clubnumber = 2 | youthyears1 = 1997–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C. Academy|Sheffield United]] | years1 = 2008–2009 | clubs1 = [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] | caps1 = 2 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2008 | clubs2 = → [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 9 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2009–2017 | clubs3 = [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] | caps3 = 183 | goals3 = 4 | years4 = 2009–2010 | clubs4 = → [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] (loan) | caps4 = 26 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2010–2011 | clubs5 = → [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (loan) | caps5 = 20 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2011 | clubs6 = → [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] (loan) | caps6 = 15 | goals6 = 1 | years7 = 2017– | clubs7 = [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] | caps7 = 57 | goals7 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2011– | nationalteam3 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps3 = 45 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 23:51, 22 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:51, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Kyle Andrew Walker''' (born 28 May 1990) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[right back]] for {{English football updater|ManchesC}} club [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
==Early life== Walker was born in [[Sheffield]], South Yorkshire<ref name=Hugman1011/> to an English mother and Jamaican father.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country}}</ref> He grew up on a council estate in the [[Sharrow]] area of the city<ref name="telegraph-ambassador">{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/tottenham-hotspur/8799568/Tottenham-Hotspur-v-Arsenal-Kyle-Walker-the-perfect-ambassador-for-Spurss-work-in-the-community.html |title=Tottenham Hotspur v Arsenal: Kyle Walker the perfect ambassador for Spurs's work in the community |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |first=Duncan |last=White |date=1 October 2011 |accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> and attended Porter Croft Infant & Junior School, followed by [[High Storrs School]] until 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/education/social-media-spells-end-of-sheffield-school-old-boys-social-club-1-6897306 |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |title=Social media spells end of Sheffield school old boys' social club |date=16 October 2014 |accessdate=7 March 2017}}</ref>
==Club career== ===Sheffield United=== Walker joined boyhood club [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]],<ref name=es>{{cite news |title=My dad was petrified I'd get killed on the M1, so I had to follow him to Northampton, says Kyle Walker |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/football/article-24011485-my-dad-was-petrified-id-get-killed-on-the-m1-so-i-had-to-follow-him-to-northampton-says-kyle-walker.do |newspaper=London Evening Standard |accessdate=18 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119233404/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard-sport/football/article-24011485-my-dad-was-petrified-id-get-killed-on-the-m1-so-i-had-to-follow-him-to-northampton-says-kyle-walker.do |archivedate=19 November 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> at the age of seven after being recommended by coach Paul Archer at [[Football Unites, Racism Divides]] and progressed through the ranks to become a regular fixture in the reserves by 2008.<ref name="telegraph-ambassador"/> In November 2008, he was allowed to join [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] on a one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to gain first team experience,<ref name="Northampton loan">{{cite web |title=Walker on the move |url=http://origin-www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1453606,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=13 November 2008 |accessdate=24 November 2008}}</ref> making his debut on 15 November 2008 in a defeat by [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]].<ref name="Northampton debut">{{cite web |title=Gray upset by defeat |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/MatchReaction/0,,10425~1435139,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=16 November 2008 |accessdate=22 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902102105/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/MatchReaction/0%2C%2C10425~1435139%2C00.html |archivedate=2 September 2012}}</ref> His one-month loan was later extended into January,<ref name="Northampton loan extended">{{cite web |title=Kyle extends loan |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10425~1494573,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=22 December 2008 |accessdate=22 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902102119/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10425~1494573%2C00.html |archivedate=2 September 2012}}</ref> before eventually returned to Bramall Lane having played nine matches for the Cobblers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Walker returns to parent club |url=http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10425~1501496,00.html |publisher=Northampton Town F.C. |date=28 December 2008 |accessdate=29 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817205302/http://www.ntfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10425~1501496%2C00.html |archivedate=17 August 2009}}</ref>
Soon after returning to his parent club, Walker made his full debut for Sheffield United on 13 January 2009, starting in a third round [[FA Cup]] tie against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]].<ref name="blades debut"> {{cite web |title=Progress – On two fronts |url=http://origin-www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Gaffersnotes/0,,10418~1520011,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=14 January 2009 |accessdate=14 January 2009}}</ref> With the Blades losing a number of players to injury in the closing weeks of the season, Walker was a surprise inclusion in the starting line up for the crucial last two matches of the season, making his full league debut for the club on 25 April 2009 against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref name="blades league debut">{{cite news |title=No qualms over role for Walker |url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/sheffield-united/No-qualms-over-role-for.5211246.jp |newspaper=The Star |location=Sheffield |date=28 April 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2009}}</ref> After two outstanding performances he retained his place as Sheffield United entered the play–offs, starting both matches against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] and the final against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] at the end of May.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} By playing in the final, Walker became the youngest Sheffield United player ever to play at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref name="Wembley Record">{{cite web |title=Kyle, the younger, steals record |url=http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/PlayerFeatures/0,,10418~1685649,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=3 June 2009 |accessdate=3 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130605122652/http://origin-www.sufc.co.uk/page/PlayerFeatures/0,,10418~1685649,00.html |archivedate=5 June 2013}}</ref>
===Tottenham Hotspur=== On 22 July 2009, Walker left Sheffield United to join [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] along with fellow defender [[Kyle Naughton]] for a combined fee of £9 million, but was loaned back to United for the duration of the 2009–10 season as part of the deal.<ref name="spurs transfer">{{cite news |title=Spurs capture Naughton and Walker |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/sheff_utd/8144711.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 July 2009 |accessdate=22 July 2009}}</ref> While at [[Bramall Lane]] he was virtually ever present at right back for the first half of the season but was unexpectedly recalled back to Spurs on 1 February 2010, just before the close of the January 2010 [[transfer window]], as cover for [[Alan Hutton]] who was loaned out to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] earlier the same day.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tottenham Hotspur recall Sheffield United's Walker |url=http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/sport/Tottenham-Hotspur-recall-Sheffield-United39s.6034450.jp |newspaper=The Yorkshire Post |location=Leeds |date=2 January 2010 |accessdate=2 February 2010}}</ref> Walker made his debut for Tottenham on Saturday 27 March 2010, in a 2–0 victory over [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]].<ref name="spurs debut">{{cite news |title=Tottenham 2 Portsmouth 0: Peter Crouch and Niko Kranjcar pile on the pain for Pompey |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1261128/Tottenham-2-Portsmouth-0-Peter-Crouch-Niko-Kranjcar-pile-pain-Pompey.html |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=28 March 2010 |accessdate=28 March 2010 |location=London |first=Ian |last=Ridley}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Kyle Walker Spurs USA tour 2010.jpg|thumb|upright|Walker with [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in 2010]]
At the start of the following season, Walker went out on loan once more signing an initial six-month deal with [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] (QPR) due to injuries at the club in the right back position.<ref name="qpr loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/8995384.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Spurs defender Walker joins QPR |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=13 September 2010}}</ref> In mid-October, his loan was extended until 3 January 2011.<ref name="extended loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/q/qpr/9093535.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=QPR extend loan of Spurs' Walker |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref>
After he had left QPR, Walker joined [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on loan until the end of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11]] season.<ref name="villa loan">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/aston_villa/9339872.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Villa sign Spurs defender on loan |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=6 January 2011}}</ref> He scored on his debut only nine minutes into the match against former club Sheffield United in the third round of the FA Cup in January 2011.<ref name="fa cup goal">{{cite news |title=A Houl lot of relief at Bramall Lane |url=http://www.people.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/fa-cup-match-reports/2011/01/09/sheffield-united-1-3-aston-villa-a-houl-lot-of-relief-at-bramall-lane-102039-22835698/ |newspaper=The Sunday People |location=London |date=9 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> At the start of February, Walker scored his first Premier League goal and first senior league goal, a 30-yard strike low into the left corner against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref name="prem goal">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9385528.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Aston Villa 2–2 Fulham |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> He returned to his parent club at the end of the 2010–11 season after scoring two goals in 18 appearances in all competitions for Aston Villa.
On leaving Villa Park, Walker suggested that he would be happy to return to the club the following season,<ref name="villa return">{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6908583,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Walker hints at Villa stay |date=1 May 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> as first team opportunities were limited<ref name="spurs options">{{cite news |url=http://www.tottenhamjournal.co.uk/tottenham-hotspur/tottenham-hotspur/ten_could_leave_spurs_as_club_plan_for_september_s_25_man_squad_1_903218 |newspaper=Tottenham Journal |title=Ten could leave Spurs as club plan for September's 25-man squad |date=25 May 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528160305/http://www.tottenhamjournal.co.uk/tottenham-hotspur/tottenham-hotspur/ten_could_leave_spurs_as_club_plan_for_september_s_25_man_squad_1_903218 |archivedate=28 May 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> but Tottenham Hotspur manager [[Harry Redknapp]] later stated that he did not wish to sell the defender.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} Walker subsequently agreed to a contract extension at Tottenham until 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_6832368,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Redknapp will not sell Walker |date=24 March 2011 |accessdate=4 July 2011}}</ref> Walker was chosen in the starting eleven for Tottenham's opening match of the 2011–12 season, against Manchester United at Old Trafford on 22 August 2011.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/aug/22/manchester-united-tottenham-hotspur "Manchester United v Tottenham live match report"]. ''The Guardian''. London. Retrieved 22 August 2011.</ref> On 2 October, he scored the winning goal in the [[North London derby]] against Arsenal from 25-yards out. Tottenham won the match 2–1.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15051273 "Tottenham 2–1 Arsenal"]. BBC Sport. 2 October 2011. Retrieved 6 May 2012.</ref>
On 22 April 2012, Walker was named as the [[PFA Young Player of the Year]], beating the likes of [[Sergio Agüero]], [[Danny Welbeck]], [[Daniel Sturridge]], [[Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain]] and teammate [[Gareth Bale]] to the award, as well as being named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=PFA>{{cite news |title=Spurs defender Kyle Walker wins PFA Young Player award |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17734248 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=15 December 2017}}</ref> On 29 April, he scored a free kick from 25 yards to help Tottenham beat [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] 2–0 at [[White Hart Lane]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17803505 "Tottenham 2–0 Blackburn"]. BBC Sport. 29 April 2012. Retrieved 6 May 2012.</ref> On 3 May 2012, Walker was awarded with a new five-year contract, that runs until 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/spurs/News/kyle-commits-to-new-deal-030512.page? |title=Kyle commits to new deal |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C. |accessdate=3 May 2012}}</ref>
Walker's performance against Manchester United in March 2012 saw him at fault for two of the opposition's goals in a 3–1 defeat.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He began his next season in a similar vein; he was at fault for Chelsea's 4th goal in the 4–2 defeat at White Hart Lane, getting shrugged off the ball easily by Juan Mata.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} He was ever-present in the first half of the season in the Premier League, with the exception of the 3–0 victory over Fulham at Craven Cottage; this included playing 90 minutes in the 3–2 win over Manchester United, which was Tottenham's first victory at Old Trafford in 23 years.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
[[File:Kyle Walker 01-09-2013 1.jpg|thumb|upright|Walker playing for Tottenham Hotspur in 2013]]
On 28 October 2013, it was announced that Walker had signed a new contract with Tottenham, keeping him at the club until 2019.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/new-contract-for-walker-281013/ |title=New contract for Walker |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=28 October 2013 |publisher=Tottenham Hotspur F.C.}}</ref>
Walker was part of the team that lost 2–0 to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at Wembley Stadium in the [[2015 Football League Cup Final|2015 League Cup Final]] on 1 March.<ref name=2015LC>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=Chelsea 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31572594 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 March 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
On 8 August 2015, Walker was involved in an own goal which led to Tottenham suffering a defeat in the hands of Manchester United in the season opener and it also became the first goal of the [[2015-16 Premier League|new season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kyler Walker's own goal gives Manchester United the win in season opener |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33744640 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 August 2015 |date=8 August 2015}}</ref>
On 20 April 2017, Walker was named as right-back in the PFA Team of the Year for the second time.<ref name=PFA1617>{{cite news |title=PFA teams of the year: Chelsea and Tottenham dominate Premier League XI |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39648483 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 April 2017 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
===Manchester City=== On 14 July 2017, Walker signed a five-year contract with Tottenham's Premier League rivals [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]],<ref>{{cite web |title=City announce signing of Kyle Walker |url=https://www.mancity.com/news/first-team/first-team-news/2017/july/kyle-walker-joins-city |publisher=Manchester City F.C. |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref> in a transfer reported to be worth an initial £45 million fee, rising to £50 million with add-ons, making it one of the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|most expensive football transfers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Kyle Walker: Man City sign right-back from Tottenham for £45m plus add-ons |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40598351 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}}</ref>
He made his competitive debut for City against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]] on 12 August 2017, a game where many media outlets labelled him as the best player.<ref>{{cite news |title=Manchester City player ratings: Kyle Walker the pick in a humdrum display |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/man-city-player-ratings-brighton-13468298 |newspaper=Manchester Evening News |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=£50 million man Kyle Walker impresses in debut, City see off Brighton |url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/manchester-city/382/blog/post/3178393/50-million-man-kyle-walker-impresses-in-debut-manchester-city-see-off-brighton |publisher=ESPN |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> However, during Walker's home debut for Manchester City he was sent off for two yellow card offences against Everton, which was thought to be a harsh decision by referee [[Bobby Madley]].<ref>{{cite news |title=City 1–1 Everton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40920114 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}</ref> Walker was selected and part of the squad that beat Arsenal 3–0 at Wembley Stadium in the [[2018 EFL Cup Final]] to claim his and City's first trophy of the 2017–18 season.<ref name=2018LC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43101681 |title=Arsenal 0–3 Manchester City |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2018 |accessdate=25 February 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Before having even made a league appearance for Sheffield United, Walker was called up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19s]] in February 2009.<ref name="england call up">{{cite web |title=Another young Blade earns England call |url=http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1547871,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=6 February 2009 |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120806003532/http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1547871,00.html |archivedate=6 August 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made his début on 10 February, coming on as a second-half substitute in a 3–0 loss to [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain U19s]].<ref name="england début">{{cite web |title=The Kyles get international cameos |url=http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1553137,00.html |publisher=Sheffield United F.C. |date=10 February 2009 |accessdate=11 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805143858/http://www.sufc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10418~1553137,00.html |archivedate=5 August 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Following his first run of regular Premier League starts, Walker was called up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad in February 2011 and again in March 2011.<ref name="full england début">{{cite news |title=Fabio Capello calls up Kyle Walker for England friendly |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9388124.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> However, he did not feature in any of the matches played and pulled out of the squad in March due to an injury.{{cn|date=April 2017}}
At the end of the 2010–11 season, Walker was named as part of the England squad which competed in the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] competition in Denmark.<ref name="england u21">{{cite web |title=Squad numbers confirmed |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/2011/englnd-u21s-squad-numbers |publisher=The Football Association |date=7 June 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Despite the poor showing of the team who were knocked out in the first round, Walker was named in the Team of the Tournament.<ref name=TOTT>{{cite news |first=Jeremy |last=Wilson |title=Tottenham Hotspur defender Kyle Walker set to make England debut against Holland |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/england/8687776/Tottenham-Hotspur-defender-Kyle-Walker-set-to-make-England-debut-against-Holland.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=16 December 2017}}</ref>
His good form in the 2011–12 [[Premier League]] season saw him named in the England squad for a friendly against [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. On 12 November, Walker made his England debut in the 1–0 win over Spain, coming on for [[Scott Parker]] as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the 85th minute.<ref name="bbc15693231">{{cite news |title=International friendly: England 1–0 Spain |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15693231.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Phil |last=McNulty |date=12 November 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref>
Walker went on to make his first start for England on 15 November, in a 1–0 win against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]], during which he won man-of-the-match.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15709627 "International friendly: England 1–0 Sweden"]. BBC Sport. 15 November 2011. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref> He missed [[UEFA Euro 2012]] because of a toe injury, suffered in a league match against Fulham.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18081125 "England Euro 2012 squad: Ruddy, Carroll & Defoe in, Ferdinand out"]. BBC Sport. 16 May 2012. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref>
Walker played the first England match after Euro 2012, playing the full 90 minutes of a 2–1 win against [[Italy national football team|Italy]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19238374 "England 2–1 Italy"]. BBC Sport. 15 August 2012. Retrieved 3 March 2013.</ref>
He was named in the 23-man [[England national football team|England national team]] squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44138600 |title=England World Cup squad: Trent Alexander-Arnold in 23-man squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 May 2018 |accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
==Sponsorship== In December 2012, Walker signed a boot deal with [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] to wear the T90 Laser IV which were also worn by [[Wayne Rooney]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.footballboots.co.uk/8325-kyle-walker-and-his-new-brand-nike.html |title=Kyle Walker and his new brand: Nike |publisher=FootballBoots.co.uk |accessdate=13 December 2012}}</ref> From 2009 to 2012, he wore the SX Valor, SX Flare, Stealth Pro, Speciali, Stealth Pro II, GT Pro, and GT Pro II boots by [[Umbro]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbible.com/boot-spotting/2012/12/kyle-walker-in-nike-switch-to-wear-t90/ |title=Kyle Walker in Nike Switch – To Wear T90 |date=12 December 2012 |website=soccerbible.com |accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref>
